SENT.plain: A four-generation Thai family affected with Van der Woude syndrome is reported
The disorder appeared to be originally inherited from a person who was half Thai and half Pakistani
The lip lesions found in this family were varied and did not appear to be related to other phenotypes
There were some clinical manifestations possibly specific for the condition in this family

They included sensorineural hearing loss, prominent frontal bone, large frontal/sphenoidal/maxillary sinuses with increased mastoid air cells, long tooth roots, dental pulp stones, ankyloglossia, brachydactyly of hands, brachyphalangy, and hyperphalangy of toes, and single flexion crease of the fifth fingers
Fluorescence in situ hybridization analysis revealed no visible deletion at a 1q32-41 region
